parts: I have git cloned a repository into WSL and made changes to it. I just realized this is not my repository. How do I upload the altered repository as my own?

thoughts.summary: Explaining Git workflow for new repo
thoughts.content: So, if the user cloned a repo to WSL and made changes locally, they want to push it to their own GitHub repo. The cleanest way: create a new repo on GitHub, then change the remote URL to point there, and push. Avoid messing with the original remote or fork; just commit locally and push to a new remote.
chunks: So, if the user cloned a repo to WSL and made changes locally, they want to push it to their own GitHub repo.
The cleanest way: create a new repo on GitHub, then change the remote URL to point there, and push.
Avoid messing with the original remote or fork; just commit locally and push to a new remote.

thoughts.summary: Providing steps for setting up a new repo on GitHub
thoughts.content: To move local changes to a new GitHub repo, you can rename the original remote to ‘upstream’ and then add your ‘origin’ (new repository URL). Push to it with `git push -u origin main`. If you don't want to keep the original history, you can reinitialize with `git init`, but this would lose commit history, which might matter depending on your goals. Don’t forget to check licensing if applicable!
chunks: To move local changes to a new GitHub repo, you can rename the original remote to ‘upstream’ and then add your ‘origin’ (new repository URL).
Push to it with `git push -u origin main`.
If you don't want to keep the original history, you can reinitialize with `git init`, but this would lose commit history, which might matter depending on your goals.
Don’t forget to check licensing if applicable!

thoughts.summary: Explaining GitHub options for uploading repo
thoughts.content: To upload a repo as your own, the best practice is to create a new repo under your GitHub account and push to it. If you eventually want to suggest changes to the original repo, it’s better to fork and push to your fork. If cloning, you must respect the existing license. Here’s a step-by-step guide with commands for both HTTPS and SSH.
chunks: To upload a repo as your own, the best practice is to create a new repo under your GitHub account and push to it.
If you eventually want to suggest changes to the original repo, it’s better to fork and push to your fork.
If cloning, you must respect the existing license.
Here’s a step-by-step guide with commands for both HTTPS and SSH.

parts:
You don’t have to “re-clone” anything — your local copy is fine. What you want to do is:

1. **Commit your changes locally**, and  
2. **Point this local repo at a *new* GitHub repo under your account**, then  
3. **Push to that new remote**.

Below is a clean way to do it from WSL.

---

## 1. Commit your changes locally

In WSL:

```bash
cd /path/to/that/repo

git status      # just to see what’s changed
```

Stage and commit:

```bash
git add .
git commit -m "Describe your changes"
```

If you already have commits, you can skip `git add/commit` unless there are new uncommitted changes.

---

## 2. Create a new empty repo on GitHub

In your browser:

1. Go to GitHub → **New repository**.
2. Set the **owner** to your account.
3. Choose a name (say `my-new-project`).
4. **Important:** Either:
   - leave it completely empty (no README, no .gitignore, no license), or  
   - if you *do* add files there, you’ll have to pull/merge them later.

Click **Create repository** and copy the repo URL, e.g.:

- HTTPS: `https://github.com/your-username/my-new-project.git`  
- or SSH:  `git@github.com:your-username/my-new-project.git`

---

## 3. Change the remote to point to *your* repo

Right now, your local repo probably has:

```bash
git remote -v
# origin  https://github.com/someone-else/their-repo.git (fetch)
# origin  https://github.com/someone-else/their-repo.git (push)
```

You have two sensible options.

### Option A – Keep original remote as “upstream” (recommended)

This preserves the connection in case you ever want to pull updates from the original repo:

```bash
# rename the current origin to upstream
git remote rename origin upstream

# add your repo as the new origin
git remote add origin https://github.com/your-username/my-new-project.git

git remote -v
# origin   https://github.com/your-username/my-new-project.git (fetch)
# origin   https://github.com/your-username/my-new-project.git (push)
# upstream https://github.com/someone-else/their-repo.git      (fetch)
# upstream https://github.com/someone-else/their-repo.git      (push)
```

### Option B – Replace origin directly

If you don’t care about keeping the old remote at all:

```bash
git remote set-url origin https://github.com/your-username/my-new-project.git
```

---

## 4. Push your repo to GitHub

Check your branch name:

```bash
git branch
# * main   (or master or something else)
```

If you want to standardize on `main`:

```bash
git branch -M main
```

Now push:

```bash
git push -u origin main
```

After this, your modified project is fully hosted **as your own repo** on GitHub.

---

## 5. (Optional) If you *don’t* want to keep the original history

If you want a “fresh” repo whose history starts from your current state (no commits from the original author):

```bash
# WARNING: this deletes all git history locally
rm -rf .git

# re-init as your own project
git init
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit"

git branch -M main
git remote add origin https://github.com/your-username/my-new-project.git
git push -u origin main
```

Use this only if you intentionally want to drop all past commits (e.g. to avoid mixing histories, or if you’re effectively treating this as a new project).

---

## 6. Licensing & attribution (non-technical but important)

Double-check the original repo’s **license**:

- If it’s MIT/Apache/BSD: you can usually reuse/modify as long as you keep the license and copyright notices.
- If it’s GPL: your derivative work must also be GPL if you distribute it.
- If there is **no license**, you technically do **not** have the right to redistribute modified code publicly without permission from the author.

At minimum, keep the original LICENSE file (if present) and any copyright headers, and don’t claim you wrote everything from scratch if you didn’t.

---

If you tell me:

- the original repo’s license, and  
- whether you want to **preserve history** or **start fresh**,

I can give you an exact, copy-paste sequence of commands tailored to your case.
